Problem:
Consider a control system characterized by the differential equation \\(\\dot{x} = Ax + Bu\\), where A is a constant matrix and B is a control matrix. An integral transformation with kernel K(x, s) is applied to the state x, yielding a transformed state \\(z(t) = \\int_0^t K(x(s), s) ds\\).

Suppose an additional controlling effect via a matrix C is added at time \\(t_1\\), modifying the system to \\(\\dot{x} = Ax + Bu + Cv\\). Will the transformed state \\(z(T)\\) for T > t_1 depend solely on the original system parameters A and B?
Explanation: The introduction of the new control matrix C as an intervention at time t_1 modifies the system dynamics, and thus affects the state x(t) and consequently z(T). The contribution of C cannot be ignored as it impacts the state trajectory past t_1.
